data.title: Jarreau first name popularity, history and meaning
data.meta_description: Find out the popularity of the first name Jarreau, what it means and the history of how Jarreau came to be.
data.text:
Find out how popular the first name Jarreau has been for the last 26 years (from 1977 to 2002) and learn more about the meaning and history.

Popularity of Jarreau by gender

Based on the last 26 years of data, Jarreau is exclusively a male name.

For the most recent data in 2002, there were 5 male babies and 0 female babies born with the name Jarreau.

The history of the first name Jarreau

The name Jarreau is a French name with roots dating back to the Middle Ages. It is thought to have originated as a derivative of the Old French word "jarret," which means "ham" or "calf of the leg." This name likely originated as a nickname for someone with a distinctive physical characteristic related to their legs or calves.

In the early medieval period, surnames were often derived from physical traits, occupations, or locations. As such, Jarreau may have initially been used to refer to someone with particularly muscular or well-developed calves, or it could have been a nickname for a person involved in the butchery trade or the handling of meat products.

One of the earliest recorded instances of the name Jarreau can be found in the historical records of the Île-de-France region of France, dating back to the 13th century. In these records, a man named Jehan Jarreau is mentioned as a landowner and merchant in the city of Paris.

Throughout the centuries, several notable figures have borne the name Jarreau. In the 16th century, Pierre Jarreau (1508-1572) was a French theologian and religious scholar who played a significant role in the Catholic Reformation movement. In the 17th century, Jacques Jarreau (1636-1701) was a renowned French architect who designed several notable buildings in Paris, including the Église Saint-Roch.

During the Age of Enlightenment, François Jarreau (1712-1778) was a French philosopher and writer who contributed to the intellectual discourse of the time. Later, in the 19th century, Louis Jarreau (1835-1892) was a French painter and artist known for his landscape and portrait works.

One of the most famous individuals with the name Jarreau is the American jazz singer and musician Al Jarreau (1940-2017). Born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, Jarreau rose to prominence in the 1970s and became known for his unique vocal style, blending elements of jazz, pop, and R&B. He won seven Grammy Awards throughout his career and was inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame in 2022.

Data source

The first name data used on this page comes from the Social Security Administration (SSA). They've been collecting data on baby names since 1880.

The history and meaning of the name Jarreau was researched and written by our team of onomatology and genealogy experts.

If you have a correction or suggestion to improve the history of Jarreau, please contact us.

Reference this page

We spend a lot of resources downloading, cleaning, merging, and formatting the data that is shown on the site.

If you found the data or information on this page useful in your research, please use the tool below to properly cite or reference Name Census as the source. We appreciate your support!
